Graphical abstract This review provides an overview of workflow of machine learning and its applications in predicting bandgap, stability, crystal structure, intrinsic properties, and solar cell performance in perovskite materials and devices. Metal-halide hybrid perovskite materials are excellent candidates for solar cells and photoelectric devices. In recent years, machine learning (ML) techniques have developed rapidly in many fields and provided ideas for material discovery and design. ML can be applied to discover new materials quickly and effectively, with significant savings in resources and time compared with traditional experiments and density functional theory (DFT) calculations. In this review, we present the application of ML in perovskites and briefly review the recent works in the field of ML-assisted perovskite design. Firstly, the advantages of perovskites in solar cells and the merits of ML applied to perovskites are discussed. Secondly, the workflow of ML in perovskite design and some basic ML algorithms are introduced. Thirdly, the applications of ML in predicting various properties of perovskite materials and devices are reviewed. Finally, we propose some prospects for the future development of this field. The rapid development of ML technology will largely promote the process of materials science, and ML will become an increasingly popular method for predicting the target properties of materials and devices. Keywords Machine learning Perovskite Materials design Bandgap engineering Stability Crystal structure 1 Introduction The amount of energy consumed worldwide is rising each year, and the finite reserves of fossil fuels cannot support sustainable energy consumption. Solar energy is the most abundant energy source, with the potential to meet the world's energy needs at a low cost and a small carbon footprint. Solar cells have now progressed to the third generation, which includes GaAs, organic polymer cells, dye-sensitized solar cells, and perovskite solar cells (PSCs) [1]. The third generation solar cells, such as PSCs, provides numerous benefits, including a high theoretical photoelectric conversion efficiency, tunable bandgap, high absorption coefficient, long carrier-diffusion length, affordable manufacturing, and a straightforward preparation procedure [2]. PSCs currently have a certified photoelectric conversion efficiency of 26.1% [3], which is higher than those of solar cells made of cadmium telluride and copper indium gallium selenium. For a long time, the approach to developing new materials has relied on trial and error. To obtain the targeted material, iterative synthesis and characterization must be conducted until a suitable material is acquired. The process can be time-consuming and expensive, while in materials informatics, new materials can be designed rationally on the basis of existing data, thereby making it possible to predict the properties of new compounds more quickly [4]. ML has a strong ability to process data, which enables it to effectively reduce the human and material costs in industrial development and shorten the R&D (research and development) cycle. By combining ML with traditional experiments or high-throughput DFT calculation, we can analyze and predict material structures more rapidly and accurately, enabling more efficient development of new functional materials. Because of this, ML technology has been rapidly applied to materials science. By employing existing data, a learning model can be developed to predict target properties of new materials [5]. Artificial intelligence (AI), also known as the “fourth paradigm of science”, has attracted worldwide attention in materials science in recent years [6]. ML has always been the core of AI. In materials science, it has emerged as a powerful tool for aiding the selection and design of diverse perovskite materials. For example, Yılmaz et al. reviewed related works based on computational data and experimental data [7]. They proposed some solutions including the judicious selection of ML techniques and the implementation of data augmentation methods to address the limitations associated with small datasets. Zhang et al. reviewed recent studies covering the prediction and understanding of lead-free and stable halide perovskite materials [8]. They proposed that more comprehensive perovskite databases are crucial for the ML process to generate ideal candidates for solar cell applications. Additionally, they suggested considering other parameters and new descriptors, such as light harvesting performance, overall conversion efficiency, and water stability. This provides a fresh perspective for the design of halide perovskite materials. In this review, we briefly discuss the successful application of ML in predicting properties of perovskite materials. In section 2, we mainly introduce the basic workflow of ML in material science and some basic ML algorithms. In section 3, we present practical applications of ML techniques in exploring diverse properties, including the band gap, stability, crystal structure, other intrinsic properties, and device performance of perovskite materials. In section 4, we discuss the current challenges and opportunities associated with the application of ML in the design and discovery of perovskite materials and propose some prospects for the future development of this field. 2 Workflow of machine learning ML is an interdisciplinary field that combines knowledge from computer science, statistics, mathematics, and engineering, forming an essential division of AI [9,10]. ML techniques incorporate computer algorithms that automatically evolve and adapt to the environment through experience, allowing the machine to make decisions and obtain knowledge. With the development of the Material Genome Project, ML is increasingly vital in materials science. For automatic prediction of materials properties and underlying relationships between structure and properties by the ML model without specialized traditional human programming, a large database is typically necessary. Typical material databases include the Inorganic Crystal Structure Database (ICSD) [11], Open Quantum Materials Database (OQMD) [12], and Materials Project (MP) [13]. Based on available data, a learning model is established to predict the properties of new materials [14]. ML has become a powerful tool to assist in the design and screening of various high-performance materials [15]. It can obtain the quantitative structure–property relationship between the physical and chemical properties of new materials and their atomic parameters, chemical formula state, process parameters, and other factors [6]. After successfully constructing the relationship model between the data, the model can be used to predict the properties of the designed materials, and synthetic characterization can verify these predictions to screen high-performance materials [16]. The general process of ML for material design is shown in Fig. 1 ; data collection, feature engineering, model selection, model verification and model application are the most important process. 2.1 Data preparation Datasets used for ML usually contain dependent and independent variables related to materials. Independent variables, also known as characteristics or descriptors, are representative information about the structural features and properties of materials, such as chemical composition, atomic or molecular parameters, structural parameters, and synthesis process conditions. The dependent variables, also known as the target variables [15,17], are the target properties of the material that are affected by the independent variables. To build a high-quality ML model, it is always essential to collect reliable datasets. The datasets generally come from experiments, databases, published papers, first-principles calculations, etc. In general, an ML model is considered more robust when it has a higher number of samples. Certain models, such as neural network (NN) and deep learning (DL), necessitate a vast number of samples [18]. However, the data obtained in actual work are generally not ideal, and there may be missing values, null values, and unevenly distributed data. For missing and null values, one can remove the problem line or replace the missing or null value with a valid value, typically the average. If there are duplicate records in the data file, the efficiency of modeling will be reduced, as most ML tools will have different structural layers, and data duplication will aggravate their impact on the results. For unevenly distributed data, which may cause the model to be more biased towards categories with larger samples, affecting model performance, reweighing bias distribution by reweighting the samples is a method. This process typically involves calculating the weights of each category so that each category contributes relatively equally to the training of the model. During training, these weights are used in the loss function to give more weight to samples from a few categories. This helps the model learn the features more accurately and improves the performance of the model on unbalanced datasets. Furthermore, data normalization are one of the common data preprocessing methods, aiming to scale the values of different features to an identical range. This helps to avoid certain features from having too much influence on the model. Common data normalization methods include Min-Max scaling and Z-score normalization. In general, for models with distance-based algorithms (e.g., SVM (support vector machine), KNN (K-nearest neighbors)), data normalization is often necessary [19]. Most of the above data preprocessing methods can be easily implemented using scikit-learn [20]. In addition, we can solve these problems by designing some data-preprocessing programs or utilizing ML platforms, such as Azure, Baidu Flying Pulp, and Google Cloud AI Platform. These platforms can provide a wealth of tools and services to help ML with data preprocessing. For example, Azure provides a hosting service named Apache Spark, which can be used for complex data transformation. Baidu Flying Pulp provides a series of APIs and tools that can perform operations such as data cleaning and enhancement. Google Cloud AI Platform provides a service named Dataflow, which can be used for large-scale data processing and transformation. 2.2 Feature engineering Any ML methods used to predict specific material properties rely on a set of descriptors. These descriptors not only uniquely define each material in the input dataset but also relate to the physical and chemical properties of the materials. In ML, the selection of the descriptor set, which should be comparable when characterizing the systems, is crucial, and different response variables should have high recognition and accuracy. Descriptors are usually derived from established properties of materials, such as ionic radius and ionization energy (IE). To avoid dimensional disasters and ensure effective training of the model without overfitting, the number of descriptors should be fewer than the number of samples in the dataset [21]. According to the relationship between evaluation criteria and learning algorithms, feature selection algorithms can be divided into three categories: Filter [22], Wrapper [23], and Embedded [24]. Lu et al. proposed the last-elimination method in gradient boosting regression (GBR) model training to effectively eliminate the less-important features when predicating the band gaps of 5158 undeveloped HOIPs (hybrid organic–inorganic perovskites) [25]. Finally, 14 important features were selected from 30 original features. Butler et al. provided a list of commonly used descriptors for elements, crystal structures and properties, during new material screening and design [26]. Wang et al. identified some well-defined and frequently utilized mathematical representations in current ML approaches for materials research based on molecular and crystal properties [27]. Multiscale intrinsic invariant-based molecular descriptors capture the underlying structure information differently from traditional molecular descriptors with higher precision and offer superior transferability to ML models. Furthermore, Ward et al. created a set of extensible attributes called Magpie that can be applied to materials with any number of constituent elements, including stoichiometric characteristic, elemental property statistics, electronic structural properties and ionic compound characteristics [28]. Additionally, Anand et al. proposed a feature-engineering method based on advanced geometric and topological invariants, which significantly improved the performance of the learning model for polymer data analysis [29]. The training results provided a significant improvement in accuracy for learning based on a persistence function compared with the model based on conventional descriptors in the design of hybrid organic–inorganic perovskite (HOIPs) materials. Experience has indicated that the Goldschmidt tolerance factor (T f), octahedral factor (O f), and ionic radius are the most commonly used structural descriptors for predicting electronic properties and formability of perovskites, while the descriptors ΔH (the energy difference between HOMO (the highest occupied molecular orbital) of HTL (hole transport layer) and HOMO of perovskite material), ΔL (the LUMO (lowest unoccupied molecular orbital) energy difference between the ETL (electron transport layer) and perovskite materials), HOMO, LUMO, and E g have a great influence on the target properties such as J sc (short-circuit current density), V oc (open-circuit voltage), FF (fill factor) and PCE of PCSs. 2.3 Machine learning technology ML can be classified into supervised learning, unsupervised learning, and reinforcement learning. Supervised learning is the most extensively used ML model as it can solve the regression and classification problems of various material systems [30]. Regression refers to the procedure of searching the prediction function when the target characteristic has continuous values, while classification is the procedure of searching the prediction function if the target has discrete values. The ML process under the supervised learning framework can be divided into four parts: data generation/acquisition, feature engineering, model training, and model application. Data generation and feature engineering have been mentioned in the previous section. After completing the data generation and feature engineering processes, the resulting data can be used for model prediction. Since each ML model is determined by multiple sets of hyperparameters, each set of hyperparameters has a different response to datasets and material characteristics. Therefore, continuous iteration is commonly used to generate optimal hyperparameters to minimize the model error. For regression models, common evaluation indexes are the mean absolute error (MAE), root mean square error (RMSE), and determination coefficient (R 2). After determining the evaluation index, it is crucial to select the appropriate hyperparameter search algorithms to achieve the best fitting performance. At present, widely used hyperparameter search algorithms include grid search, random search, and Bayesian optimization [20,31]. 2.4 Common ML algorithms in the field of material design As a classical supervised learning algorithm, the core principle of support vector machine (SVM) is to map vectors to higher dimensional space and subsequently establish a hyperplane within this newly generated space [32,33]. Normally, there are two aspects that need to be considered in the process of ML prediction. For the classification problem, we should maximize the distance of data points from the hyperplane, thereby minimizing the overall total error. For the regression problem, the distance between the data points and hyperplane should be minimized. Fig. 2 (a) briefly illustrates the case of two-dimensional classification. The key to SVM is the data dimension, which is typically expressed through the use of a kernel function [34]. SVM performs well on small sample data sets and can effectively deal with sparse data and unbalanced samples. In the field of materials science, SVM can provide reliable predictive performance, particularly in situations where sample sizes are limited. The decision tree (DT) algorithm is designed to understand the problem as a tree structure similar to the flow chart [35]. Each leaf node in the tree represents the selection of features, the branches of the tree indicate the test results of each feature, and each leaf node of the tree represents a category. DT usually includes three parts: feature selection, decision tree growth and pruning. The algorithm iteratively divides the data into subsets according to the feature values and selects the optimal feature to split the dataset, generating a tree-like structure where internal nodes indicate decision rules and leaf nodes indicate outcomes, as shown in Fig. 2(b). Known for its interpretability and user-friendliness, the DT excels as a potent tool for predicting material properties and discovering correlations between different features. At the same time, the decision rules generated by DT model are easily understood, which can help researchers to comprehend the relationship between material properties and characteristics. The integrated algorithm is a method combining multiple individual models. By doing so, it can learn the strengths of each model and compensate for their respective weaknesses to generate a more comprehensive ML model (Fig. 2c). Currently, the commonly used integration methods are bagging, boosting and stacking [36,37]. Bagging involves creating multiple instances of a model, each trained on various subsets of the data, to reduce the variance of the model. Boosting, however, focuses on minimizing bias by iteratively training models on the data and giving more weight to samples that were misclassified in previous iterations. Stacking involves combining the predictions of multiple models, often with different architectures or hyperparameters, to achieve greater accuracy. Integrated algorithms can assist in the analysis and interpretation of complex data sets, such as those obtained from experiments or simulations, thereby enabling a more extensive understanding of material properties. These algorithms can significantly enhance the overall prediction accuracy by combining the prediction results of multiple basic models. Different base models may have different biases and variances, and integrating their prediction results can reduce errors and enhance the accuracy of prediction. Artificial neural network (ANN) is a mathematical model based on the basic principle of neural networks in biology [38,39]. By comprehending and abstracting the structure of the human brain, as well as its response mechanism to external stimuli, ANN simulates the processing mechanisms of the human brain's neural system for complex information based on network topology knowledge. ANN is an operational model composed of numerous nodes (neurons) connected to each other. Each node represents a unit for processing information, which can accept information and output information. The output information achieves non-linear mapping through an activation function. Fig. 2(d) shows an example with two outputs and three features as inputs. ANN's superiority in material science lies in its ability to handle complicated, non-linear relationships between material properties and their underlying factors, including chemical composition, crystal structure, and processing conditions. Also, ANN is fault-tolerant to noise and incomplete information in the input data. It can automatically adapt and correct the noise in the data, reduce its impact on the model prediction, and improve the robustness and stability of the model. Convolutional neural network (CNN) is another popular neural network that distinguishes itself from ANN in the way it automatically acquires and extracts features from multiple channels [40]. While CNN's primary focus is on the processing of image and video data, it has also proven effective in material science and performs better than traditional ML in specific circumstances. Xie et al. developed a crystal graph convolutional neural networks (CGCNN) framework to directly learn material properties from the connection of atoms in the crystal, which offers a universal and interpretable representation of crystalline materials [41]. CNN generally includes several convolutional layers and pooling layers in addition to input and output layers, as shown in Fig. 2(e). The convolutional layer extracts input features, while the pooling layer is typically followed by the convolutional layer, reducing feature mapping size and retaining important information. The primary advantage of the CNN lies in its ability to deepen hidden layers, making it particularly effective on large datasets. In summary, SVM exhibits superior performance on small sample and high-dimensional datasets. However, it is sensitive to the selection of kernel functions and outliers. DT offers notable interpretability, capable of handling non-linear relationships, yet it is prone to overfitting. Integrated learning enhances overall performance by combining the predictions of multiple leaners, and demonstrates robust resistance to overfitting. Consequently, it is currently the most widely applied method in this field. ANN and CNN excel in capturing complex non-linear relationships, typically demonstrating proficiency on large-scale datasets. Nevertheless, their tendency to overfitting on smaller datasets, coupled with the requirement for meticulous tuning of numerous hyperparameters, result in their limitations. There is often no uniform optimal ML algorithm for different materials research problems. The selection of the appropriate model in material science research should be based on the available data, as well as the prior knowledge and assumptions relevant to the specific research problem. This process requires a comprehensive understanding of the material properties and their relationships with the variables and parameters of the system. For instance, simple structure–property relationships may be analyzed by linear regression (LR) or DT-based models, whereas complex materials discovery tasks might require more advanced algorithms such as RF (random forest), SVM or DL methods. Zhao et al. systematically studied the fitting precision effects of different ML models on perovskite system structure and band gap, and further explored the relationship between perovskite structure and properties [42]. The results demonstrate that the ML models show similar trends for different fitting target properties, and all nonlinear integration models display excellent fitting results, which stems from the implementation of a range of integration methods that optimize the high variance and bias of a single model. Twelve ML algorithm models were trained and compared based on their evaluation indexes. The model with the best fitting effect is the extreme gradient boosting decision tree (XGBoost), which can also provide important descriptor information for analyzing the thermodynamic stability and band gap of mixed-halogen perovskite materials. Therefore, materials science researchers usually need to carefully evaluate and choose the ML algorithm that most suits the particular features and demands of their research issue. This selection process may entail trialing various algorithms, conducting feature engineering, and optimizing models to obtain optimal outcomes for a given materials research problem. 3 Application of machine learning in perovskite material design 3.1 Bandgap engineering in perovskites using ML Bandgap engineering is a crucial technique for perovskite ABX3 to adjust its capacity to absorb light and can impact the efficiency of photovoltaic devices based on perovskite, such as photosensitive detectors, solar cells, and light-emitting diodes. Perovskite has outstanding optoelectronic properties and its bandgap can be tuned to absorb a wider spectrum. Due to the selective flexibility of perovskite composition, the A, B and X ions can be replaced by a variety of elements, offering a broad range of tunable bandgaps. Experimentally exploring and selecting all potential structures demands immense effort. Consequently, it is more efficient to use ML techniques to predict the bandgap of a range of perovskites and identify suitable candidates for different applications. Lu et al. developed a targeted-driven method to predict possible HOIPs for solar cell application through ML prediction and DFT calculations, and the overall workflow is shown in Fig. 3 (a) [25]. A dataset of 346 HOIPs was used for the ML model, which is obtained from high-throughput first-principles calculations and experiments in the literature [43,44]. Only orthorhombic-like crystal structures and bandgaps calculated using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional were chosen for data consistency and ML prediction accuracy. Finally, 212 compounds are selected for this engine. The input samples for the ML model in this work consist of 11 small organic molecular species (A-site), 32 divalent metals (B-site), and 4 halogens (X-site), as shown in Fig. 3(b). For feature engineering, the GBR algorithm was used to evaluate the feature importance [45]. At the same time, a “last-place elimination” method was developed to generate effective features to effectively eliminate the less important features. Finally, 14 important features were selected, including T f, O f, total number of ionic charges (IC B), p-orbital electrons (Xp−electron), ionization energy (IE B), electronegativity (χ B), electron affinity (EA B), ionic polarizability (P B, P A), sum of the s and p orbital radii (r B s+p ), R B (ionic radius of the B site), R A, and the HOMO and LUMO of A-site cations. As shown in Fig. 3(c), the feature importance of these 14 descriptors was ranked and the Pearson correlation (r) among the features was analyzed to generate the heat map. These features were applied to different ML algorithms (GBR, KRR (kernel ridge regression), SVR (support vector regression), GPR (Gaussian process regression), DTR (decision tree regression) and MPR (multilayer perception regression) to evaluate the performance of each ML model. Through the evaluation-index coefficient of determination (R 2), Pearson coefficient, and mean square error (MSE), the GBR algorithm fitted the training set best as the DFT-computed and predicted bandgaps match very well (Fig. 3d). Eventually, among 5158 unexplored HOIPs, six orthorhombic lead-free HOIPs with direct bandgaps in the visible region were successfully selected and show excellent thermal stability at room temperature. However, same problem exists in this ML model as others. Application of this model or method in other broader areas such as other more organic cations in A-site or anions in X-site may face following challenges: (i) Accurate estimation of organic ionic radii or processing ionic radius data from various sources in the literature is still an open challenge. (ii) Some of the substituted structures may induce distortion after structural optimization even if their T f and O f are in compliance, so further stability validation was needed. Normally, the identification of compounds with direct bandgaps is preferred, as it can greatly accelerate the study of more-effective light-harvesting materials. As inorganic perovskites can offer both compositional flexibility and stability, Smarak Rath et al. used ML to predict the bandgaps of inorganic perovskite and divided them according to direct and indirect bandgaps [46]. The dataset of this work is based on the MP database, which contains 1528 ABX3 formula compounds. For the structural composition of this kind of perovskite, the A sites and B sites are occupied by cations (Ac, Ag, Al, Ba, Bi) and X is an anion (O, F, Cl, Br, I, S, Se, Te, N, or P). The relevant features were then generated using Matminer’s “Meredig” module, yielding 129 descriptors [47]. We believe that utilizing opensource toolkits such as Matminer's module may be a good general approach to build feature engineering for inorganic materials. Then the Pearson coefficient was used in feature engineering to evaluate feature correlation. Features are considered highly correlated when the Pearson coefficient is greater than 0.8. A total of 118 features were finally selected for training the model after removing redundant features. In order to test the prediction accuracy of seven ML algorithms, ten-fold cross validation was used. In comparison with other seven algorithms, XGBoost exhibited the highest classification accuracy. The prediction accuracy of the model was improved using RandomizedSearchCV to adjust the hyperparameters. Ten-fold cross-validation was performed on each algorithm, and Table 1 displays the precision, recall, F 1-scores for predictions on the test set, and the average classification accuracy. Class 0 represents indirect band gap material and class 1 represents direct band gap material. It is found that the prediction accuracy for direct bandgap materials with XGBoost is 81%, and the presence of Si, Cs, Sb, K, or F in a compound would increase the likelihood of possessing a direct bandgap, while the presence of a transition metal in a perovskite would reduce the probability of possessing a direct bandgap. It is concluded that transition metals should be avoided in the synthesis of inorganic ABX3 perovskite for light-harvesting applications. 2D HOIPs have also attracted considerable attention because of their intriguing optoelectronic properties and enhanced stability compared to 3D perovskites. Wan et al. created an ML approach based on molecular graphics and adjacency matrices for the purpose of determining bandgaps of 2D HOIPs more efficiently [48]. The general research framework is shown in Fig. 4 (a). Through model training and prediction, bandgaps of 524 unexplored 2D HOIPs were determined. A data set of 136 2D A2BX4 HOIPs for ML training of this work was selected from the 2D perovskite database built by Marchenko et al [49]. For these 2D A2BX4 HOIPs, the A site is a monovalent organic cation, the B site is a divalent metal cation, and the X site is a halide ion. The component elements for each location are shown in Fig. 4(c). The feature engineering of the model is based on molecular structure information characterized by molecular graphics and adjacency matrices to establish simple descriptors. The PaDEL descriptor developed by Yap et al. was introduced into this work [50]. In order to reduce the complexity of the ML model, the multiple stepwise regression (MSR) algorithm was used to select important descriptors. With the help of MSR analysis, six important features without collinearity were obtained and further used in the training of 16 ML models. The results indicate that the R 2 of the ANN model in the test set is 0.98, demonstrating the model's outstanding ability to fit and predict externally, with no overfitting issues. Eventually, five potential two-dimensional HOIPs with excellent photoelectric performance were discovered with potential application in solar cells, and four of them are lead-free. Despite the rapid development of lead-halide perovskites in solar cells within a very short time because of their excellent PCE and low cost, the inclusion of lead ions has hindered their commercialization due to their impact on the environment and human health. Among the many lead-free perovskites, double perovskite with the formula A2B+B3+X6 has been proposed and incorporates cation transmutation, in which two Pb2+ are replaced by one M+ cation and one M3+ cation. The particular elements for each site are shown in Fig. 4(b), and a total number of 540 hypothetical compounds were considered. Jino et al. used the GBR algorithm based on a DFT-calculated electronic structures dataset to predict the heat of formation (ΔH F) and bandgap of halide double perovskites in order to find potential candidate lead-free perovskites for solar cells [51]. In this work, 32 descriptors were selected as the initial feature sets taking both atomic composition and geometry information into account. In the process of feature engineering, the significance of each feature was assessed and prioritized, with the less significant features being eliminated recursively. Under the process of extracting key-features, it was found that the prediction errors (RMSE) of ΔH F and E g increased monotonically, indicating that a feature with a higher feature score had stronger predictive power. The most crucial descriptors were then chosen for each target property. The final chosen descriptors for ΔH F included χ X (Pauling’s electronegativity for the X site), D B 3 + (atomic distance (D) between cations and the nearest halogen atom), D B 1 + , D A and h B 1 + (highest occupied atomic level for the B1+ site) within an RMSE of 0.036 eV. In the case of bandgap, the selected features were SG (space group of the crystal), χ X , h B 1 + , l B 1 + (lowest unoccupied atomic level for the B1 + site), D B 3 + , rd B 3 + (d valence orbital radii for the B3+ site) and rd B 1 + within an RMSE of 0.322 eV. By extracting the relationship between features and target properties, one could search for the optimal double-perovskite solar cell materials. For example, symmetry lowering by tilting of the octahedral unit of a halide perovskite can increases E g because of bandwidth shrinkage, while partial-substitution/alloying for In and Ag can reduce the E g due to the electronegativity of halogen anions. The authors also revealed that discrepancies in the electronegativities of bonding partners are reliable indicators of the character and strength of the bond, which has a significant impact on ΔH F. This study provided guidance in the search for lead-free PSCs. Gladkikh et al. employed a small-sample ML technique, alternating conditional expectations (ACE), to predict the bandgap of ABX3 perovskites [52]. ACE was proposed by Breiman and Friedman in the 1985s [53]. The advantage of ACE is that it is primarily displayed through visual representations. At the same time, ACE transformations demonstrate the importance of each feature to the target property. The ACE method has the advantage of avoiding the curse of dimensionality, as its calculation uses a univariate function. For the training set, there are only 126 samples but there are 1256 features. The training results showed that electronegativity, electron affinity, IE and atomic radius have the greatest influence on the bandgap. To evaluate the performance of the model, ACE was contrasted with traditional ML techniques, including DT, kernel ridge regression (KRR), and ensemble trees. The training results demonstrated that ACE outperformed the other ML methods. Furthermore, ACE has the added benefit of visually representing data, facilitating comprehensibility. In contrast, the interpretability of ensemble methods and KRR is less clear. Subsequently, ACE exhibits excellent performance in out-of-sample data validation. However, the ACE method depends on the provided feature set and sample set. Different feature selection methods may lead to different results, and we suggest that careful evaluation of their limitations and further development of their potential prospects. In addition, Takahashi et al. analyzed data for 15,000 ABC2D perovskites (similar to compounds like BaNbO2N, RbTiO2F, PbTaO2N) and used the random forest (RF) classification model to predict the potential application of 9,328 perovskite materials for solar cell applications [54]. For these perovskite materials, the formation energy is lower than 0.5 eV and the bandgaps are in the range of 1.5 to 3.0 eV; also, their thermodynamic stability was verified by first principles calculations. The results proved that the 10 undiscovered perovskite compounds predicted by ML were ideal materials for light harvesting. With the help of this method, they proposed a new double-chalcogenide perovskite that could potentially replace CH3NH3PbI3. The average performance of the RF and SVM algorithms was evaluated over 200 training trials, considering the inclusion and exclusion of the A-site cation properties. By comparison, the RF algorithm exhibited superior performance to the SVM and was consequently adopted. Finally, when considering the bandgap and light absorption, Ba2AlNbS6, Ba2GaNbS6, Sr2InNbS6, Ca2GaNbS6 and Ba2SnHfS6 were found to be the most promising candidates for solar cells. Due to the complex structure of HOIDPs (hybrid organic–inorganic double perovskites), they have not been thoroughly studied so far. Zhang et al. accelerated the discovery of HOIDPs by combining ML techniques, high-throughput screening, and DFT calculations [56]. The input dataset included two datasets with various HOIDPs chosen for training ML models. Then the accuracy of the ML model is further improved by using low-level calculations as the baseline to predict high-level methods. Specifically, the authors regarded the geometric shape of organic cations at the A site as a cuboid rather than spherical. The shape of organic cations is irregular, and a cuboid with three parameters (length, width and height) is more suitable to describe the geometric shape of organic cations than a sphere with only one parameter (radius). It is worth noting that the generality of the cuboid-based organic cation model with three parameters deserves to be further investigated. In addition, the HOMO-LUMO gap and rotation temperature of A-site cations were introduced to improve the accuracy of the model. Fig. 4(g) compares the bandgap calculated by DFT with the bandgap forecasted by the ML models. The outcomes demonstrate that the ML approach accurately predicts PBE and HSE06 bandgaps. Among these, 17 compounds have bandgap between 1.5 and 3.0 eV, and 2 compounds have smaller bandgaps (0.76 and 1.44 eV, respectively). The results also demonstrate that Tl-based HOIDPs, which have been studied less often, tend to possess suitable bandgaps. Although the results still need to be verified, considering the anisotropy and implementation of Δ-ML can further improve the HOIDPs-discovery performance of ML, and that work demonstrates an effective method for predicting and discovering hidden novel photovoltaic materials. In photocatalytic water splitting, the bandgap is also a crucial parameter for determining the light-absorption capacity. Tao et al. designed an ML platform to predict the bandgap of ABO3-type perovskite materials [57]. The 124 samples were divided randomly 100 times into the training set and the testing set at a ratio of 4:1. Researchers collected 20 initial features, including 17 atomic parameters generated from an online computation platform for materials data mining and 3 experimental conditions extracted from references. The models were built using the commonly utilized algorithms of backpropagation neural network (BPNN), SVR, GBR and RF. Furthermore, the Max Relevance Min Redundancy (mRMR) approach was employed to screen the optimal feature subset for SVR and BPNN models, while the embedded method was used for feature screening for GBR and RF models. The average r values were 0.9010 and 0.9125 in 100 training and testing models, respectively, ensuring the models’ robustness and generalization. Then the best-performing GBR model was employed to predict the bandgaps of the 4,915 perovskite oxides.
