This work also developed user-friendly and publicly accessible web servers to predict the bandgap of ABO3-type perovskite materials, which could provide beneficial guidance towards accelerating material design and optimization and extend the scope of ABO3-type perovskite materials. Bandgap engineering is an important method to control the light-absorption capacity of perovskite. Because the electronic properties of perovskite are highly sensitive to structural changes, the prediction of the bandgap of perovskite is challenging. On the one hand, by using ML techniques, perovskite candidates with appropriate bandgaps can be quickly predicted, while saving valuable resources and increasing efficiency. On the other hand, we emphasize the importance of domain experts’ knowledge for ML, especially in small-sample situations, where the model may be subject to limited features and samples, and omit features that are actually important, as in the famous “No free lunch theorems” [58]. Different feature engineering methods usually have different feature importance assessments, and how to select optimal feature subsets may require the utilization of a priori knowledge. Based on these examples of bandgap engineering, we conclude that the total number of ionic charges, ionization energy, electronegativity, electron affinity, ionic polarizability, sum of orbital radii, and the HOMO and LUMO of cations are likely to be features that have a large effect on the bandgap of perovskites. In addition, Bandgap as well as its property (directly or indirectly) can often be finely tuned by component engineering, and the works of utilizing ML to predict component ratios based on bandgaps or to predict bandgaps based on component ratios may become increasingly common in the future. 3.2 Stability predication of designed perovskites using ML Formability and stability issues are crucial in perovskite research and are challenging to tackle. For a long time, assessments of perovskite formability and stability relied on semi-empirical models, such as T f and O f. However, T f and O f are not effective descriptors to accurately evaluate the stability and formability of perovskites [59,60]. By taking into account T f, O f and atomic packing fractions (η), Yin et al. proposed a novel descriptor (T f + O f) η for predicting stable perovskites [61]. They established a database of decomposition energies for 354 halide perovskites based on high-throughput DFT calculations. The 354 compounds include single perovskites and double perovskites. Through the establishment of four groups of feature sets: (i) T f, (ii) (T f + O f) η , (iii) R A, R B,eff, R X, and (iv) R A, R B1, R B2, R X, an ML technique was used to learn the mapping relationships between each feature set and decomposition energy (ΔH D). Other features, such as electronegativity, were discarded because they exhibited overfitting during training. It is found that a smaller number of features in their work has the following advantages: First, the model is less prone to overfitting. Second, fewer features improve the interpretability of the model, making the scientific knowledge of the domain intuitively clear. Based on the results presented in Fig. 5 (a), it can be observed that the feature set comprising R A, R B1, R B2, and R X demonstrates the highest level of accuracy according to the values of R 2 and RMSE. When R B(I) and R B(III) were taken into consideration individually, the prediction accuracy of relative stability and formability was increased. Therefore, this set of descriptors was used as the feature set to predict the decomposition energy of 14,190 single- and double-halide perovskites. According to the stability condition ΔH D > 0, 2,275 perovskites out of 14,190 were predicted to be stable. The most stable class for A2B(I)B(III)X6 is AX = CsCl, which consists of 473 perovskites with average ΔH D of 82.7 meV/atom. The prediction accuracy of the ML model was evaluated by comparing its results with the DFT calculations for 74 perovskites selected randomly and 246 experimental data. This comparison verified the reliability of the ML model. Meanwhile, a map of the overall stability of the mixed perovskite based on the predicted results revealed that the stability of the perovskite can be enhanced by mixing different proportions of cations and anions at the A, B, and X sites [62,63]. Thermodynamic phase stability is an important parameter affecting the stability of perovskite and plays a crucial role in determining whether the compound can be synthesized and whether it will be degraded under certain conditions. Li et al. used ML techniques to predict thermodynamic phase stability of oxide perovskites [64]. The dataset for training the model came from Jacobs et al., which was calculated using DFT [65]. The dataset for that work included 71 ternary (e.g., LaMnO3), 1,248 quaternary (e.g., La0.75Sr0.25MnO3), 601 quinary (e.g., La0.5Sr0.5Co0.25Fe0.75O3), and 9 sextenary perovskite oxides. In that work, the ML task was mainly divided into two parts: (i) Classification of stable and unstable perovskites (Fig. 5c); (ii) stability regression prediction of perovskite based on the E hull value. Based on the threshold of E hull = 40 meV/atom, perovskites were classified as stable and unstable. In comparison of five kinds of ML algorithms, the results of the Extra trees training model scored highest in accuracy, precision, recall and F 1, proving it is the best model to distinguish the stability of perovskite. Finally, 567 stable perovskites were obtained. As shown in Fig. 5(d), most compounds (85%) were predicted with the RMSE error below 28 meV/atom. Meanwhile, the model was cross-validated by five subsets, demonstrating its good classification and regression performance, even with limited component information in the training set. Considering the complex crystal structures, multi-objective properties, and large search space of lead-free HOIDPs, Cai et al. presented a multi-step and multi-stage ML technique [66]. The average formation energy, bandgap, and Debye temperature of HOIDPs were predicted by establishing multiple regression models in turn. Finally, 597 stable A2BB'X6 HOIDPs with suitable bandgap and high Debye temperature were obtained from 180,023 potential candidates (32 monovalent organic molecular cations for the A site, 9 monovalent, 49 divalent, and 35 trivalent B/B′-site cations, and 4 X-site anions: F, Cl, Br, I) through model training [43,44]. According to the requirements of non-toxicity and experimental feasibility, 12 candidates were selected from the 597 perovskites. Then DFT calculation confirmed that four perovskite materials meet the necessary criteria. The four perovskites are (CH3NH3)2AgAlBr6, (CH3NH3)2AgGaBr6, (CH3NH3)2AgInBr6, and (C2NH6)2AgInBr6, which have much larger thermal conductivities by an order than CH3NH3PbI3. This can be explained by the larger stiffness inducing much larger Debye temperature, which can override the anharmonic interactions effect. With the help of ML technology, the prediction results of the bandgap model were almost consistent with experiments, and the multi-stage bandgap prediction scheme could ensure the reliability of the results. Due to the neglect of growth conditions and synthesis kinetics, the thermodynamic metric is not sufficient to evaluate the synthesizability of virtual materials. Therefore, Gu et al. [67] developed an ML scheme based on graph neural network to accurately predict the synthesizability of all classes of perovskites, including chalcogenide, halide, and hydride perovskites, as well as anti-perovskites. They technically combined positive-unlabeled learning (Fig. 5b), domain-specific learning, and transfer learning to construct the prediction model. The training set for model training consisted of 943 experimentally synthesized perovskites and 11,964 virtual perovskites obtained from the MP, OQMD, and AFLOW databases. Pre-training and transfer learning were all performed by position-unlabeled learning, and 10% synthesized crystals were randomly sampled from the MP database to test the model. The formability of perovskites was judged by the CL score (synthesizability score) (Fig. 5e). Compared with the non-domain-specific original model with the accuracy of approximately 74%, the model with domain-specific learning and transfer learning has a high out-of-sample positive data accuracy of 95.7% (Fig. 5f). From 11,964 predicted perovskite materials, they screened 962 synthesizable perovskites, and 179 of them had been experimentally synthesized in the previous literature, confirming the reliability of the model. Compared to the currently available models for predicting the stability of perovskite materials, this method has an advantage in that it is not limited by the type of material and can predict the stability of all classes of perovskites and anti-perovskites. This work used a large amount of real experimental data to predict the synthesizability of perovskite, ensuring the effectiveness of the model in practical applications. Future research could focus on integrating information about growth conditions and synthesis kinetics into ML models. This would provide a more comprehensive understanding of the factors affecting the synthesizability of perovskite materials and enhance the predictive performance of the models under different experimental conditions. Zhang et al. proposed an interpretive ML strategy to speed up the discovery of potential HOIPs [68]. This method combined ML with a Shapley additive explanations (SHAP) approach and employed 102 samples as a training set. The elemental composition of the 102 perovskites included two A-site cations ([CH3NH3 + and HC(NH2)2 +], 14B-site cations (Be2+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Cr2+, Mn2+, Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Hg2+, Sn2+, and Pb2+) and 4 X-site anions (F−, Cl−, Br−, and I−). The results of the leaving-one-out cross-validation (LOOCV) demonstrated that XGBoost outperformed other models with a predictive accuracy of 0.95. According to the prediction of the model, 198 non-toxic candidates with a P f (probability of formability) over 0.99 were selected from 18,560 virtual samples. SHAP analysis showed that the features R B (ionic radius of the B site) and LC B (the lattice constant of the B site) are positively correlated with formability, while R A (ionic radius of the A site), T f (tolerance factor), and I 1B (the first ionization energy of the B site) are negatively correlated with formability. The SHAP analysis was also used to evaluate the significance of the model. It provides not only global explanations, but also local explanations at the level of individual prediction instances, making model easier to understand and interpret. In their work, the combination of ML and SHAP method demonstrated high prediction efficiency of formability of perovskites with limited features, and the screened candidates were expected to be synthesizable. Perovskite oxide has aroused great interest because of its wide potential applications. It is found to have fascinating electrical and magnetic properties, such as ferroelectric and piezoelectric properties, optical properties, high-temperature superconductivity and magnetostrictive properties [69–72]. The tunability of these properties can be enhanced by the method of increasing the compositional complexity via the double perovskite-ordered configuration containing multiple cations. This characteristic makes materials like perovskite attractive because it allows for the straightforward substitution of any atom in the perovskite structure to precisely tune the desired physical properties. Tunability may be increased further when two different types of cations occupy the A site or B site of perovskite with the formula A x A 2 - x ' B 2 X 6 and A 2 B y B 2 - y ' X 6 for x ≥ 0 , y ≤ 2 . Anjana et al. proposed a multipronged approach to predict the formability and thermodynamic stability of single- and double-perovskite oxides [73]. The initial training set was created using a combination of DFT calculations and data from the literature. There were ∼1505 and 3469 data points in the training data sets to predict the formability and stability of single- and double-perovskite oxides, respectively [74–76]. The formability evaluation assessed the probability of a given compound's successful experimental synthesis as a perovskite. Therefore, the training data set was based on experimental data. The thermodynamic stability refers to how well a composition will stabilize in a perovskite structure according to its position relative to the convex hull of the system. In feature selection, recursive feature elimination (RFE) in the scikit-learn python package was used to select features by recursively eliminating those that have been given the least weight by an additional tree classifier. Finally, 28 features were generated, including symmetric and antisymmetric compound features and geometric features. Meanwhile, RF was selected to predict the formability and stability of perovskite based on 28 features. The accuracy, precision, and recall values for the formability classification model were 0.9401, 0.9344, and 0.9913, respectively. In addition, the accuracy, precision, and recall values for the thermodynamic stability classification model were 0.941, 0.933, and 0.936, respectively. All the evaluation indicators indicated that the classifier used has good performance. After training and testing, the classification models for formability and stability were used to predict a comprehensive chalcogenide dataset, which contained 946,292 different compounds. Among these, 891,188 compounds were predicted to be formable, while 437,828 compounds were predicted to be stable. More than 99% of the predicted stable compounds are a subset of the formable compounds. This conclusion underlined the fact that formability is a more liberal metric than thermodynamic stability. As a result of the intersection of this large chemical space of formable and stable oxide perovskites, 414 novel compositions were identified as the most promising candidates for future experimental synthesis of novel oxide perovskites. The issue of formability and stability is the focus and challenge of perovskite research. Previous studies indicate that ML models can effectively map the potential relationship between structure and chemical properties. Unlike the bandgap, it seems that ionic radii, lattice constant, T f and ionization energy are more relevant to the stability of perovskite materials. With sufficient training data from high-throughput DFT calculations, ML-based studies on perovskite formability and stability are far more cost-effective and efficient than laboratory studies. However, there are different indicators of stability evaluation, such as formation energy, decomposition energy, the energy above the convex hull and formation probability, each criterion is only applied to a specific small dataset. Therefore, establishing a unified criterion closely associated with stability may be crucial, which can combine different pre-existing datasets to train models with better generalization performance and more robustness. 3.3 Crystal structure predication of perovskites using ML The prediction of crystal structure has long been a challenge for condensed matter and materials science. So far, most advanced crystal structure prediction methods combine structure search with DFT simulation [77–85]. Yin et al. developed an ML method for crystal structure prediction using graph networks (GN) to establish a correlation model between crystal structure and enthalpy of formation in a given database, followed by an optimization algorithm (OA) to find the crystal structure with the lowest enthalpy of formation [86]. The input data sets used to train the GN model mainly come from two benchmark databases (open quantum materials-OQMD and Matbench-MatB). Random searching (RAS), particle-swarm optimization (PSO), and Bayesian optimization (BO) were used as optimization algorithms (OAS). After predicting the crystal structures of 29 octet binary compounds, the results indicated that the GN model combined with BO trained on MatB exhibited the best performance when predicting the crystal structure. The lattice constants of 28 compounds were predicted by this model, and the error rate was 2.24% with an atom energy of 20.8 meV/atom in terms of absolute energy difference (Fig. 6 b). Although the predictive accuracy of this method is slightly lower than that of DFT calculations, it can predict crystal structures with three orders of magnitude computational cost less than DFT computation. The study opened up a new avenue for data-driven crystal structure prediction. Hirshfeld surface analysis is a straightforward tool for describing molecular packing, close contact points, molecule shape, and intermolecular interactions. The Hirshfeld surface is sensitive to crystal structure, stoichiometry and defects related to the chemistry and occupancy of the local sites. Williams et al. introduced an ML method for predicting perovskite lattice parameters based on a 3D Hirshfeld surfaces representation of crystal structure [87]. In larger systems, such as distorted or double perovskites, some atomic locations will be located deep within the traditional Hirshfeld surface. Therefore, among the fingerprint points represented by the Hirshfeld surface, these sites are not obvious. The researchers modified the traditional Hirshfeld surface used for molecular crystal characterization. They employed fingerprints made up of a set of Hirshfeld surfaces for each specific atomic site in the crystal structure to solve this issue. Since all atoms were treated equally, the ambiguity of unit cell selection was eliminated. A 3D Hirshfeld surface could be converted into a rotationally invariant 2D fingerprint through measuring d i , d e of each surface point and integrating them into a 2D histogram (Fig. 6a). The ML approach used in their work was based on CNN and the training set was cubic perovskites selected from OQMD. The framework of the CNN model is shown in Fig. 6(c). For the accuracy of the prediction, CGCNN was also used to compare with CNN, and they used the same training set and test set. Hirshfeld surfaces fingerprint plus CNN was found to have a better accuracy according to R 2, MAE, and MSE. In order to assess the applicability of that proposed method against experimental data, as well as small data sets and non-oxides, the data of a similar work by Kuzmanovski et al. [88] were used for training for comparison, and the proposed method achieved a more accurate prediction than the method established by Kuzmanovski et al. This work established the accuracy of the Hirshfeld surface fingerprint combined with deep learning trained by experiment or computational data prediction and provided a new approach to explore the structure–property relationship related to complex crystal chemistries by data-driven high-throughput calculation. Advanced structure searching and ML methods can be utilized to find the crystal structure. However, the compositional space of chemical compositions and crystal structures of different perovskites is huge and complex, and the computational and ML methods are still facing a great challenge. Recently, an ML-Based Adaptive Genetic Algorithm (AGA) structure prediction framework has been developed for crystal structures of binary and ternary compounds [89,90], and we believe it may be more suitable for perovskite materials prediction. 3.4 ML application to intrinsic properties of perovskites In the field of materials science, the application of traditional ML algorithms, such as DT, ensemble learning, and ANN, is limited by their inability to provide meaningful physical laws. In contrast, symbolic learning, as an interpretable ML algorithm, can not only search for the best mathematical equation but also identify optimal parameters for materials. As a result, symbolic learning is capable of providing interpretable mathematical formulations that offer explicit instructions for materials design. Other intrinsic properties, such as defect physics, electronic and ion conductivity, are also important for characterizing perovskite, and can be used for screening the application of materials. With the aids of ML method, we can effectively determine the potential applications of perovskites in diverse fields. In order to determine the association between oxygen vacancy defect formation energy and structural factors, Liu et al. developed a descriptor classification model [91]. Firstly, the training set was mainly selected from the oxide perovskite database calculated by Antoine et al. [92]. Next, 3,430 potential ABO3 inorganic oxide perovskites were selected from the database, in which the A and B sites are inorganic metal cations. Since the energy required for defect formation is affected by temperature, the prediction model is closer to the actual defect formation in the experiment. Meanwhile, considering the preparation method, 0.5 eV was set as the cut-off energy for the oxygen vacancy formation energy. The matching structural parameters and the formation of oxygen vacancies of each perovskite were used to explore new descriptors. The feature set was divided into 9 groups, and each group of features was tested by n folds cross-validation to evaluate feature factors, which were the harmonized average of accuracy and roc_auc_score. Next, the population size, genetic generation and hyperparameters of the genetic algorithm model were selected through test tuning. Through 5 cross-validations, it was found that the model achieved the best balance between accuracy and time efficiency when the population size was ∼10,000 and the generation number was ∼20–30. Through model training, the structural feature K was finally established, which is represented as K = n a ( r a E na - r b ) , where n a is the valence of the a-site ion, r a is the radius of the a-site ion, E na is the electronegativity of the a-site ion, and r b is the radius of the b-site ion. By establishing a mapping function between K and probability, one can effectively judge the likelihood of forming oxygen vacancy defects in a perovskite. The model predicted that it is not likely to form oxygen vacancy defects when K > 0. As a result, symbolic classification can correctly classify the condition of synthesis of oxygen vacancy defects in perovskites when dealing with smaller data sets without a predetermined physical basis. Such interpretable ML algorithms have the potential to enable the discovery of structure–property relations of new materials. The physical and chemical properties of perovskite can be severely affected through defect engineering. The defect formation energy is an important measure of defect stability and is usually obtained via experiment and/or through DFT calculations, both of which are expensive and time-consuming. Sharma et al. applied an ML technique to determine the factors that affect the defect formation energy in perovskite oxides [93], ABO3. BaTiO3 of the cubic (c-BTO) phase, rhomboid (R-BTO) phase and LaMnO3 of the cubic (c-LMO) phase were considered. Forty-four dopants were systematically substituted at either the A or B sites, and the substitutional defect formation energy training dataset was generated with ab initio DFT calculations. In the feature engineering, 13 features were selected that represent either atomic or bulk elemental properties of the dopant in comparison to the substituted host cation species. Random forest regression was used to predict the stability of doped c-BTO and c-LMO. Using a 90%–10% train-test segmentation, the RMSE errors on the training and test data sets were 0.59 and 0.98 eV, respectively. As shown in Fig. 7 (a), this work visually analyzed the correlation of screened features with the defect formation energy in the R-BTO dataset. The four most-important features were selected through a down-selection method and exhibited substitutional-site-dependent trends with the dopant formation energy. The prediction performance of the test set or the error on unseen data was less than 1 eV, suggesting that the trained model enabled the identification of relevant substitutional dopants for a given host with an accuracy that falls within this energy range. Then the model was successfully used to predict the stability of doping in c-BTO and c-LMO. Mannodi-Kanakkithodi et al. used DFT in combination with ML to provide predictive models and quick identification of photoelectrically active impurities [94]. The training set was based on the calculated defect formation energy and 4 transition levels (ε(q/q−1), q ∈ [+2, +1, 0, −1, −2]) of 265 samples. Descriptors were selected as 19 features related to elemental and unit cell defect features. Using regression techniques such as GPR, NN, and RF, the calculated impurity properties were mapped. The Gaussian process regression model provided the lowest error. RMSE values of the formation energy and transition level predicted by GPR were 0.59 and 0.32 eV, respectively. On this basis, hundreds of impurities in nine MAPbX3 compounds were predicted and a list of impurities that can change the equilibrium Fermi level determined by intrinsic point defects in perovskite were created, as shown in Fig. 7(b). This work could guide the identification of problematic impurities that may lead to undesired charge-carrier recombination, as well as impurities that can be deliberately introduced to regulate perovskite conductivity and photovoltaic absorption. Furthermore, this work could have implications for intermediate-band PV applications. These results demonstrated the efficiency of the ML tool in identifying and quantifying the dependence of different characteristics, and provided a promising pathway for selecting dopants in perovskite according to specific demands, which may potentially be applied to other material classes. In addition, with the accumulation of defect-related data, it is becoming possible to calculate and predict the ion mobility energy barriers of various perovskite defects, which influences the ionic conductivity and carrier mobility of materials. The combination of high-throughput calculations and ML helps to rapidly predict and screen the electrical and conductive properties of materials to accelerate the design of novel perovskite materials for use in electronic devices or batteries. In the area of green energy technologies, such as alkali ion batteries, gas separation membranes, and solar cells, the overall ionic, electronic, and hybrid conductivity plays a crucial role. However, these applications are mostly limited to high temperatures (800–1000 °C), where various chemical reactions and carrier transport are relatively fast. In certain cases, elevated temperatures can lead to increased polarization resistance, making the reduction of desired resistance a significant area of current study. Over the years, the main research interests have been focused on obtaining higher conductivity at lower temperatures. For this purpose, the ability to quickly and accurately identify solid oxides with high electrical conductivity is important for the application of materials with resistive properties. Due to the low efficiency of the experimental and DFT calculation methods, Priya et al. [95]. developed an ML model that can effectively and accurately predict the conductivity of perovskite directly by using material properties available in the published literature. The dataset for ML contained 7,000 data points from the literature. Undoped and doped perovskites with high electrical conductivity were screened by ML regression, and they were classified by ML based on charge carrier type. The overall design framework is shown in Fig. 7(c). The important chemical features of the regression model are the minimum electronegativity and mean ionic radius of B-site ions. As for the classification model, its important characteristics are the minimum atomic mass of the B-site ions and the minimum formation energy of the B-site oxide. For exploring stable pure perovskites, they screened type I and type II perovskites for higher conductivities at temperatures of 600 and 400 °C and classified them according to their majority charge carriers. The conductivity results for type I perovskites screened at 400 °C indicate that some perovskite compounds such as iridium, osmate, bismuth, platinate, and lead-acid have high conductivity and are mainly classified as proton or mixed proton/electron conductive oxides under wet H2/air conditions, and thus they can be used as hydrogen separation membranes or fuel cell electrodes. At the temperature of 400 °C, they found highly conductive type II perovskites such as manganate, antimonate, vanadate and ferrate. According to the analysis results, the conductivity of type II perovskite is usually lower than that of type I perovskite. Considering the stability of perovskite, the screening criteria are energy above hull <0.05 eV at 0 K and tolerance factor T f between 0.7 and 1.1 at 300 K. In addition to screening the perovskites based on stability, they also screened the perovskites of type I and type II based on the lower activation energy for conductivity, as shown in Fig. 7(d). According to the lower activation energy of conductivity and higher conductivity at 400 °C in humid air, the best-performing proton type, oxide type, mixed oxide/electron type and mixed proton/electron type were selected. By comparing the literature value and predicted value of activation energy, it was found that the RMSE was 0.047 eV. Finally, candidates with high conductivity such as BaBiO3, BaTbO3, PmEuO3, CeErO3, EuPbO3, SrTiO3, EuGeO3 and CaPtO3 were selected. At the same time, the ML model was used to screen compounds doped at the A and B sites, and their stability was considered. The researchers found that at low dopant concentrations (<5%) when there is no phase separation, M2O3-doped oxide was used for type I perovskite and MO-doped oxide was used for type II. Over 4,000 hybrid perovskite proton conductors with better conductivity than the widely-known BZY (BaZr0.8Y0.2O3–δ) were discovered, as well as 300 promising materials for oxide ion conduction. In summary, the researchers utilized ML techniques to facilitate the design and discovery of ABO3 perovskite oxides with diverse applications in the field of energy. A robust learning framework was described in order to predict the overall conductivity of perovskites and classify them based on their charge carriers under various temperatures and environmental conditions. Fig. 7(e) depicts a comparison between the XGBoost model predictions and experimental outcomes, with the x-axis representing the experimental observation. Finally, 1,793 undoped and 95,832 A- and B-site-doped AO + BO2 (5% M2O3) and A2O3 + B2O3 (5% MO) perovskites for high conductivities were screened, and they can be used for different energy applications, depending on the type of the charge carriers. This work demonstrates the exploration of different environmental conditions, such as varying temperatures, and their impact on the conductivity of perovskites. This can broaden the model’s applicability and provide insights for practical applications. 3.5 ML application to perovskite solar cells In addition to the applications in designing perovskite materials, ML is also frequently applied in the area of PSCs to help predict and design device performance including PCE, V oc , J sc , FF, etc. It can also assist in guiding fabrication and uncovering the underlying mechanisms of PSCs. The functionality of PSCs highly relies on the experimental parameters, specifically regarding the perovskite compositions and fabrication processes. Lu et al. implemented ML techniques to examine the impact of these parameters on device performance on a dataset including 1,072 devices with PCE greater than 10% from previously published articles [96]. To construct the feature engineering, 17 features of the perovskite components, including additives, solvent, antisolvent, ETL, interface layer and effective device area were screened. The target outputs were the photovoltaic parameters, including PCE, V oc , J sc and FF. A comprehensive description of the 21 features identified is provided in Table 2 . The results indicated that PCE is significantly correlated with the effective area, A-site cations, additives, halogen ratio, and ETL properties. Then the models were established using five ML algorithms, including LR, NN, RF, XGBoost and GBDT (gradient boosting decision trees). XGBoost outperformed all other algorithms on the test set. The RMSEs of the model in predicting PCE, V oc , J sc , and FF were as low as 1.28%, 29 mV, 0.813 mA/cm2, and 0.033, respectively. Additionally, the SHAP interpreter was used to rank the factors that determine the device's performance, and the A-site cation was found crucial to obtaining highly efficient PSCs (Fig. 8 a). Experiments and DFT calculations were conducted to validate results predicted by the ML model. The device performance was also dramatically improved by engineering the A-site cation components, with a notable increase in the PCE from 18.20% to 21.43%. This work demonstrated the feasibility of ML in predicting device performance from experimental parameters before experiments, enabling reverse experimental design towards highly efficient PSCs. Despite significant progress, PSCs have yet to fully realize their potential, especially with regard to the low V oc . The primary problem behind this limitation appears to be the well-discussed issue of non-radiative recombination losses occurring at the perovskite interface. Consequently, the strategic optimization of interfaces has emerged as the main approach for enhancing PSCs device performance. In a study conducted by Liu et al., ML was employed to map the relationship between the interface material and the device performance, intelligently screening interface materials towards minimizing voltage losses in p-i-n type PSCs [97]. Firstly, the dataset was established by summarizing the experimental reports on utilization of additives or interface materials for p-i-n PSCs, resulting in a dataset comprising 303 data points. Then, molecular descriptors were used to represent the materials, which enhances the interpretability of the ML models. These descriptors were derived from modified materials, perovskite precursors, and control device performance metrics. The electron topological-state index was used to represent the modified materials from the atomic level, which encoded the unification of electronic and topological information within the chemical environment. Additionally, the cheminformatics features, such as the molecular complexity and the topological surface area, were incorporated as input features. To avoid over-fitting, the feature dimension was reduced from over 300 to 29. Among these features, six features were identified as the most important in determining modified V oc , with controlled V oc exhibiting the strongest positive correlation (0.69). Next, four ML algorithms were employed to predict the V oc , including LR, RF, XGBoost and NN. The optimization of algorithm hyperparameters was carried out using a 10-fold cross-validation. Among the models tested, the RF model outperformed the others with a lower RMSE (26.3 mV) and the highest r-value (0.83) on the test set, as shown in Fig. 8(b and c). Having established the robustness of the RF model, the researchers employed it to predict the performance of PSCs based on 20 interface materials, with ThMACl and ThEACl emerging as the top-performing materials in terms of enhancing V oc . Furthermore, the scope of the study was expanded by screening an additional 39 new materials, offering valuable guidance for the discovery of more favorable interface-modifying materials. ΔH and ΔL also play important roles in the performance of PSCs, and Fig. 8(d) illustrates these energy level differences schematically. These two factors affect the hole transfer from perovskite to HTL and the electron transfer from perovskite to ETL, respectively. According to the Marcus theory, excessively high ΔH or ΔL will cause a significant energy loss at the interface between the perovskite and HTL/ETL, which ultimately results in limited PCE of the device [98]. Zhang et al. developed a dual-strategy ML model based on NN [99]. This model consists of a perovskite composition design module (PCDM) and a carrier transport layer relative characteristic design module (CTLDM). Firstly, PCDM predicts the composition ratio of perovskite materials based on expected performance. CTLDM then designs energy-level matching based on the first predicted outcomes and the target performance. For PCDM, the researchers used the data in Perovskite Database Project, and 972 sets of data were randomly divided into the training set (90%) and test set (10%). The input features consist of PCE, V oc , J sc , FF and the bandgap of perovskites, and the target output is the perovskite composition. The model’s performance was also evaluated in comparison to other classical ML algorithms, including LR, RF, and SVR, using the same datasets. In the test set, the proposed method yielded an RMSE of 0.067, with r-values for all ions exceeding 0.89. The method demonstrated no significant performance differences among different elements, owing to its use of a one-dimensional convolutional layer that possesses a strong collective reasoning capacity, as shown in Fig. 8(e). Consequently, it takes into account the predictive capabilities of each element, while simultaneously achieving the highest overall performance. For CTLDM, the dataset was supplemented by additional research articles. Ultimately, 400 sets of suitable data were obtained. The input features include perovskite composition and the initial performance parameters, and the output is the recommended values for ΔH and ΔL. Their algorithm also demonstrated the best performance among all the algorithms. To further assess the ability of the model to guide actual experiments, the researchers fabricated the corresponding PSCs and used the actual experimental results obtained to further evaluate the performance of the model. Eventually, acceptable results were obtained, demonstrating the potential for this method to be employed in an actual experimental process. In summary, the PCE of PSCs is subject to the influence of a multitude of factors. These factors include not only the composition of the perovskite material itself but also extend to the careful selection of ETL and HTL materials, the intricacies of the device preparation process, the judicious inclusion of additives, and the design of energy levels (ΔH and ΔL). In addition, the thickness and stability of the perovskite layer, alongside the strategic architectural design of the photovoltaic device, emerge as crucial factors impacting PCE. The optimization of these multifaceted factors, often facilitated through the application of ML techniques, represents a crucial avenue within the ongoing research trajectory of PSCs. This optimization pursuit seeks to augment PCE and propel the field toward greater efficacy and sustainability. 4 Summary and outlook ML can accelerate the screening and prediction process for perovskite materials. Through the development of suitable models and algorithms, materials with potential applications can be quickly identified from a large number of candidate materials, resulting in significant savings of both time and resources. In this work, we present the relevant details from related research papers and offer a summary of the research in Table S1 and S2 in Supporting Information. ML algorithms can accurately predict various properties of perovskite materials through careful selection of training sets, test sets and descriptors. Also, the performance of photovoltaic devices, including solar cells, can be predicted by ML techniques. The properties of perovskite materials are often influenced by several parameters, such as composition, crystal structure, impurities, etc., and ML can process and optimize these multi-parameter problems to find the most suitable combination to meet a particular performance requirement. Firstly, data on perovskite materials is often limited and scattered, which may lead to errors in the data collection and labeling process. Hence, the effectiveness of an ML model is heavily reliant on the quality and quantity of its training dataset. To achieve high-quality data collection, we propose to normalize databases for each material feature and property. As an example, ionic radius is typically a crucial feature for predicting properties of perovskites. However, the widely generalized Shannon ionic radii only cover inorganic elements and there is quite a bit of missing information on coordination numbers. The establishment of a database including both organic and inorganic ion radii, which can be realized by standardizing the method for evaluating the ionic radii or using the existing data to predict the elusive organic cation radius by ML, is expected to solve this problem. The standardization and improvement of the database will benefit the performance of ML, and in turn the improved ML models will make the predicted data more reliable and dependable, which will create a positive cycle in this field. In addition, traditional ML models often exhibit poor generalizability performance due to the lack of sufficient training data. Machine learning potential (MLP), in which atomic coordinates, energies, and forces are collected to build a dataset, could greatly benefit from direct training models using data acquired from large databases, like MP. Recently, Bowen Deng et al. put forward a universal MLP framework, namely CHGNet, demonstrating the potential for universal MLPs that may not require chemistry-specific training [100,101]. This framework may inspire ML approaches targeting a narrow range of chemistries and insufficient training data. Secondly, interpretation and interpretability are another challenge. The properties and behavior of perovskite materials are often driven by complex physical and chemical mechanisms, and ML models typically provide predictions in a black box format that lacks explanations. This makes it difficult for scientists to understand the decision-making process and results of the models, limiting the depth of understanding of the intrinsic laws of perovskite materials. To enhance the interpretability of the ML model, in addition to the previously mentioned feature importance analysis and SHAP explainer, we recommend combining domain experts’ knowledge with model explanations to better understand the model's output. Domain experts can provide contextual information about features, data, and the model that aids in interpretation. Another possible approach is creating detailed documentation and reports that record the model’s construction, training, and interpretation methods, as well as performance and interpretability assessment results, which helps other researchers understand and validate the model. Thirdly, the efficiency of computational resources and algorithms is also a challenge. Computational simulations and ML training of perovskite materials typically require substantial computational resources and time. Therefore, we suggest that the development of efficient algorithms is crucial for saving computational resources. In addition, implementing transfer learning which can transfer learned features and parameters to new domains is also a low-cost strategy to reduce training expenses. Finally, existing ML tools heavily rely on programming languages and skills, raising the difficulty for materials scientists to entry this field. Therefore, we propose the development of more universal materials ML platforms. On one hand, these platforms would enable researchers without specialized ML knowledge to leverage these powerful tools for materials research, enhancing their efficiency in materials design and discovery. On the other hand, they would contribute to standardization, bolstering research reproducibility, thereby accelerating materials innovation. We believe that with the rapid development of computational methods and modern computer technology, ML will be more widely used in materials science (e.g., photovoltaic materials). coredata.dc:description: Metal-halide hybrid perovskite materials are excellent candidates for solar cells and photoelectric devices. In recent years, machine learning (ML) techniques have developed rapidly in many fields and provided ideas for material discovery and design. ML can be applied to discover new materials quickly and effectively, with significant savings in resources and time compared with traditional experiments and density functional theory (DFT) calculations. In this review, we present the application of ML in perovskites and briefly review the recent works in the field of ML-assisted perovskite design. Firstly, the advantages of perovskites in solar cells and the merits of ML applied to perovskites are discussed. Secondly, the workflow of ML in perovskite design and some basic ML algorithms are introduced. Thirdly, the applications of ML in predicting various properties of perovskite materials and devices are reviewed. Finally, we propose some prospects for the future development of this field. The rapid development of ML technology will largely promote the process of materials science, and ML will become an increasingly popular method for predicting the target properties of materials and devices.
